The dynamics of the last "boom" make a long "limping along" period pretty difficult to imagine. I ran across this article just a little while ago:
 
 http://www.nytimes.com/2008/04/09/business/09leonhardt.html?em&ex=1207886400&en=37ecbcf28a0d85b5&ei=5087%0A
 
 
For Many, a Boom That Wasn't
 
 How has the United States economy gotten to this point?
 
 It's not just the apparent recession. Recessions happen. If you tried to build an economy immune to the human emotions that produce boom and bust, you would end up with something that looked like East Germany.
 
 The bigger problem is that the now-finished boom was, for most Americans, nothing of the sort. In 2000, at the end of the previous economic expansion, the median American family made about $61,000, according to the Census Bureau's inflation-adjusted numbers. In 2007, in what looks to have been the final year of the most recent expansion, the median family, amazingly, seems to have made less - about $60,500.

 
 The consumer spending component of the economy has remained a relatively static 70% so if wages are not increasing that can only mean that much of the economic expansion we have seen over the last decade or so has been based primarily on debt. That tracks with what we know about private debt holdings in the US. Americans, especially the middle class, are up to their eyeballs in debt. While you can drag out an economic decline for a very long time, you cannot drag out a debt implosion like a typical economic decline. Debt expansion eventually hits a brick wall and you get an abrupt "correction". 
 
 We are seeing this in the mortgage market right now. Mortgage defaults have not crept up a percent or two at time, they have jumped by double digits. Credit card defaults are starting to do the same, due in no small part to the fact that (as utterly moronic as it may be) a lot of people have been charging the bejesus out of their credit cards and then refinancing their homes every year to clear the cards. Now that the refi tap has been turned off, a lot of people have been caught with credit card debts that they cannot possibly afford. 
 
 The bad thing is that we have not even SEEN recession yet and its effect on your average American. We have seen a few jobs lost, but nothing big yet. As the effects of recession set in and more people lose their jobs, etc... we will see more defaults, which will lead to tighter lending, which will lead to further economic slowdown, etc... We have already seen the beginning of the spiral.

Current account deficits have reached extreme levels across much of the ex-Soviet bloc, hitting 22.9pc in Latvia, 21.4pc in Bulgaria, 16.5pc in Serbia, 16pc in Estonia, 14.5pc in Romania and 13.3pc in Lithuania.
 The IMF said lenders in Eastern Europe had built up "large negative net foreign positions" during the boom, especially in the Baltic states. "Liquidity for these banks has all but dried up and [interest] spreads have widened 500 basis points."
 Many of these countries rely on credit from branches of West European and Nordic banks, but these foreign lenders are having difficulty raising money on the global capital markets.
 "A soft landing for the Baltics and south-eastern Europe could be jeopardised if external financing conditions force parent banks to contract credit to the region. Swedish banks, the main suppliers of external funding to the Baltics, could come under pressure," it said.
